a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:01): anyway, fwiw, the way the obsolete-element handling is implemented in v.nu is that the obsolete elements are part of the v.nu/whattf HTML5 RelaxNG schema -- treated as valid (that's the only way to get the schema to recognize them -- but an additional assertions-checking step further along in the processing pipeline then catches and reports them
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:01): but why is it different than an equivalent style attribute?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:02): it's not. style="" attributes are just as bad and should be limited to things like prototyping and temporary workarounds.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, ok, is style="" obsolete in HTML5 as well?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:03): it was, for a long time. there are some edge cases for which it is useful (primarily prototyping), which is why it is currently allowed.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, <font> works better for fragments

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:05): there are ample essays on the subject on the web that can enlighten you on the subject though.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:05): well, no one invited you to argue it. carry on!

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (02:19): hsivonen: I wonder if it would make sense to switch the order of processing in v.nu such that the assertions checking is done prior to the schema checking in the processing pipeline
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:20): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: "how does it lead to inaccessible sites?" it doesn't _necessarily_.

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:20): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: Presentational markup can produce inaccessible sites indirectly if style rather than semantic markup is depended upon for communication.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:20): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, I definitely agree there are bad things
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:21): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, I don't think "presentational markup" is a meaningful term however
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:21): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: You can (of course) produce exactly the same accessibility problem using generic elements (hello div and span) plus CSS.

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:22): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: do you think "markup conveying formatting information rather than explicitly implying the type of content and its relationship to other content" is meaningful?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:22): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, no
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:22): sometimes, yes. but not as a general principle
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:22): when yes and when no?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:23): or, why yes when yes, and why no when no
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:23): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, presentational information can lend context to words in the same way that intonation can when words are spoken

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:24): there's a difference between humans inferring information from context and machines inferring informationm, that they can then present to humans in a regularized fashion, from explicit instruction.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:24): accessibility is about humans, I though
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:24): thought
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:25): yes. and being about to regularize information into a tailored format is about making information accessible to humans.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:25): *able to
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:25): I think the goal is a good one
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:26): I'm not sure banning the <font> element is going to help much
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:26): I could see the value of doing that if one could say "rest assured, you are creating an accessible site" in its absence
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:27): Why would you expect it to be a silver bullet?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:27): that is not what I said
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:27): or what I meant, rather
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:27): Seems implied in what you said. Can you rephrase perhaps?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:28): banning <font> does not prevent the exact problems we are discussing
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:28): since they are all still there with different markup
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:29): the substitution of ambiguous formatting information for (more) unambiguous information about types and relationships?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:29): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, my view is that these elements are syntactic sugar for CSS properties
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:29): they are no more evil than the CSS, and it takes some judgement to figure out whether they are ok
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:30): I think it's confused to say they are syntactic sugar for CSS properties.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:31): Because what's "objectionable" about font and style is that they bake formatting information into the structured content layer.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:31): that is not an accessibility objection
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:32): I definitely agree that there are maintainability concerns, and accessibility concerns

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:34): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: If your point is it's possible to bake formatting information into the structured content layer, without making it impossible for a machine to separate the two, that's strictly true.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:34): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, concrete examples are better
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:34): Concrete examples of what, sorry?

14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:35): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, can you create something that is strictly worse, from an accessibility perspective, that is only enabled by <font> or <center>?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:40): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: "enabled", probably not. "encouraged", probably yes. encouragement isn't enablement though.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:40): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, ok, I believe that might be true. what is an example?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:41): an example of encouragement?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:41): I am particularly interested in cases that aren't of the form "you aren't smart enough to understand CSS"
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:41): Not entirely sure what that means.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:42): I think the context is WYSIWYG and the idea that by changing the font you've communicated that something is e.g. a heading, or a field label, or some code.

14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:42): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, it seems to me that lots of things we consider to be "good markup" are getting mixed up. Good maintainability, good accessibility, etc.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:43): Mmm. "mixed up" or ... happen to be produced by the same practices.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:43): and a lot of it is motivated by a sophomoric division of "presentation" and "data"
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:43): "sophomoric" seems like a way to criticise something without having to actually state your criticism.
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:44): that is not the definition! :)
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:44): but anyway, "the idea that by changing the font you've communicated that something is e.g. a heading, or a field label, or some code"
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:44): but do we get an element for each visual subtlety out there?
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:45): Not in HTML.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:45): CSS came along before that happened! ;)
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (02:45): ok, we're in the same place I think
